docs.snippet: While on Seventh Avenue in Park Slope, Brooklyn, one scorching day last summer, I stopped at Moe's, a Mexican takeout spot, for a cold tamarind drink. The scent of sweet spices and fried dough wafted through the air. A man held a foil pouch contai...
docs.abstract: Moe's, Mexican takeout spot in Park Slope, Brooklyn, is popular for its rice pudding empanada; photo (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: While on Seventh Avenue in Park Slope, Brooklyn, one scorching day last summer, I stopped at Moe's, a Mexican takeout spot, for a cold tamarind drink. The scent of sweet spices and fried dough wafted through the air. A man held a foil pouch containing what looked like a flat calzone with a creamy filling. It was a rice pudding empanada, and I had to try one. A slim turnover emerged from the deep fryer and was thickly dusted with cinnamon sugar. Beneath the flour tortilla crust was rice pudding, firm and almost candylike. I bought one ($1.89) and finished it before I was halfway down the block.

docs.snippet: Proof that Artisanal, 2 Park Avenue (32nd Street), is about more than cheese comes from a refreshing melon ''cocktail'' with a ginger and Sauternes-lime gelée. Though served as a hot-weather first course, it could as easily be a dessert. To make ...
docs.abstract: Refreshing melon cocktail with ginger and Sauternes-lime gelee is being served at hot-weather first-course at Artisanal, but could easily be dessert; photo (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: Proof that Artisanal, 2 Park Avenue (32nd Street), is about more than cheese comes from a refreshing melon ''cocktail'' with a ginger and Sauternes-lime gelée. Though served as a hot-weather first course, it could as easily be a dessert. To make it at home for six, start early in the day. Soften a teaspoon of plain gelatin in a tablespoon of cold water, bring two cups of Sauternes to a boil with a quarter cup of lime juice, remove from the heat and whisk in gelatin. Refrigerate until jelled. Whisk thoroughly and chill for two hours more. Scoop about eight cups of small melon balls (seven or so pounds of untrimmed melon). Place a tablespoon of the gelée in each of six martini glasses, add the melon and the rest of the gelée. Top with slivers of crystallized ginger mixed with strips of lime zest.

headline.main: Melon Balls At the Top Of Their Game

docs.snippet: It had been a while since I'd been out with foodies, and I let my guard down.    We were convening at Craft, a new restaurant near Gramercy Park. It was the place all foodies were talking about. ''Can you believe how expensive it is?'' one shrieke...
docs.abstract: Amanda Hesser Food column on dining with New York 'foodies' at Craft; restaurant recipes; photo (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: It had been a while since I'd been out with foodies, and I let my guard down. We were convening at Craft, a new restaurant near Gramercy Park. It was the place all foodies were talking about. ''Can you believe how expensive it is?'' one shrieked. ''I had the worst service ever!'' Another griped: ''Those leather walls are horrid. And the menu -- preposterous!'' That's how foodies talk. No one is ever optimistic about a restaurant for fear of looking silly if the place tanks. Better to predict doom and then be smugly triumphant.

docs.snippet: Great looking and deceptively inexpensive, these hand-hammered, stainless-steel serving pieces are just right for summer weekend house gifts. The collection, Geometrics, by the American metalware designer Michael Aram, is made in India. The pieces...
docs.abstract: Michael Aram designs geometrics tableware set; photo (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: Great looking and deceptively inexpensive, these hand-hammered, stainless-steel serving pieces are just right for summer weekend house gifts. The collection, Geometrics, by the American metalware designer Michael Aram, is made in India. The pieces coordinate with his other utensils, usually made of silverplate. This group -- a serving set of a 10-inch fork and a spoon, $45; an 8-inch cake server, $24; and cake knife, $20 -- is all available at Arcadia, 261 West 19th Street. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

docs.snippet: Call it the muffin connection. When Jean Kahn decided to close her bakery-cafe, Les Friandises, at 972 Lexington Avenue (70th Street), to work with her husband, Rafet Senturk, in Dalga, his new Turkish seafood restaurant on East 62nd Street, the f...
docs.abstract: Amy Scherber, owner of Amy's Bread, opens another branch at Lexington and 70th Street; photo (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: Call it the muffin connection. When Jean Kahn decided to close her bakery-cafe, Les Friandises, at 972 Lexington Avenue (70th Street), to work with her husband, Rafet Senturk, in Dalga, his new Turkish seafood restaurant on East 62nd Street, the first thing she did was to call Amy Scherber, the owner of Amy's Bread, whom she knew professionally. It was not hard to persuade Ms. Scherber to take over the place for a branch of her Chelsea and Ninth Avenue bakeries. You'll recognize the turquoise-striped awning, like the one shading Amy's Bread at Ninth Avenue and 46th Street. And you'll also recognize Ms. Scherber's signature semolina breads, black olive twists, layer cakes and sandwiches. New at this store are wedges of quiche, $4, and hearty salads with vegetables, grains, chicken and fish, $6 to $7.

headline.main: From One Baker to Another: Amy's Bread Answers a Call

docs.snippet: Cool materials and bright colors -- the sweet nothings of summer fashion -- are dressing this summer's tables.    Paper mats and matching napkins from France come in two patterns. Black Dots, left center, for the minimalist, and Grass, below, for ...
docs.abstract: Colorful tableware is right for summer; photos (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: Cool materials and bright colors -- the sweet nothings of summer fashion -- are dressing this summer's tables. Paper mats and matching napkins from France come in two patterns. Black Dots, left center, for the minimalist, and Grass, below, for the naturalist. They are $8 for a package of 10 mats and $8 for 20 napkins. At the MoMA Design Store, 44 West 53rd Street.

docs.snippet: ¡Gusto! is the ''Buena Vista Social Club'' of food magazines. A glossy new offering from the publishers of Cooking Light, it's aimed at Latinos but feels as infectiously inclusive as Cuban music.    Flip past the feature on nail treatments and yo...
docs.abstract: Gusto! is new food magazine aimed at Latinos; photo (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: ¡Gusto! is the ''Buena Vista Social Club'' of food magazines. A glossy new offering from the publishers of Cooking Light, it's aimed at Latinos but feels as infectiously inclusive as Cuban music. Flip past the feature on nail treatments and you'll find step-by-step photographs on making empanadas and pithy articles on the food of innovative Latino and Anglo chefs, like Douglas Rodriguez in New York and Norman Van Aken in Miami, and traditionalists like Penelope Casas. The recipes are all tempting, whether for Ecuadorean potato-cheese patties or anchovy and pimento tapas with pine nuts.

docs.snippet: Uncommonly pale, about the shade of rose Champagne, and smooth and well toned, this smoked salmon stands out from the rest. It is not farm-raised like most salmon destined for the smoker but is caught in the Baltic Sea and cold-smoked in Denmark. ...
docs.abstract: Danish smoked salmon is available at Russ & Daughters in lower Manhattan, and several other places; photo (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: Uncommonly pale, about the shade of rose Champagne, and smooth and well toned, this smoked salmon stands out from the rest. It is not farm-raised like most salmon destined for the smoker but is caught in the Baltic Sea and cold-smoked in Denmark. It combines a delicate brininess with overtones of sweet charring and could be a treat for that New Year's Eve dinner -- or for a morning-after brunch. Sliced to order, it is $36 a pound at Russ & Daughters, 179 East Houston Street (Allen Street), or $45 a pound at Eli's Manhattan, 1411 Third Avenue (80th Street) and the Vinegar Factory, 431 East 91st Street.

headline.main: From the Wild, by Way of Denmark

docs.snippet: Two young women have taken ''singing for your supper'' to new heights. Meredith Greenberg and Leora Perlman (her father is the violinist Itzhak Perlman), conservatory-trained opera singers, met in 1994 while performing in a music festival at Chaut...
docs.abstract: Divas' Delite, new catering company on Upper East Side, offers opera-themed meals served by people who can sing; drawing (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: Two young women have taken ''singing for your supper'' to new heights. Meredith Greenberg and Leora Perlman (her father is the violinist Itzhak Perlman), conservatory-trained opera singers, met in 1994 while performing in a music festival at Chautauqua, N.Y., and soon discovered that they shared an interest not only in opera but also in cooking. The result was Divas' Delite, their new catering company based on the Upper West Side. Their bill of fare has operatic names, like Puccini's Choice and Bizet's Buffet. No, their set menus don't offer Chinese food as homage to Turandot, or Wagnerian bratwurst or schnitzel, for that matter. But the partners say they can put together a menu that fits your music of choice, and they'll perform operatic favorites and even rewrite lyrics to personalize them for a special occasion.

headline.main: Dinner at Home, With a Libretto on the Side

docs.snippet: The National Audubon Society, which is concerned about the finned as well as the feathered, has published the Seafood Lover's Almanac, a colorful guide ($19.95) to the habitats of various fish, crustaceans and mollusks and the methods used to catc...
docs.abstract: National Audubon Society publishes Seafood Lover's Almanac, colorful guide ($19.95) to the habitats of various fish, crustaceans and mollusks and the methods used to catch them; photo (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: The National Audubon Society, which is concerned about the finned as well as the feathered, has published the Seafood Lover's Almanac, a colorful guide ($19.95) to the habitats of various fish, crustaceans and mollusks and the methods used to catch them. There are also some cooking tips and recipes. Each species is rated, from green to yellow to red -- with red being the worst -- on the Audubon Fish Scale, a gauge of whether it is endangered and whether harvesting methods cause pollution or threaten other species. Among the imperiled are the Patagonian toothfish (a k a Chilean sea bass) and swordfish. (King mackerel, above, gets a green.) To order: (888) 397-6649.

headline.main: Before Ordering Surf, Read About Turf
